titleStmt.title: Myoglobin facilitates angiotensin II-induced constriction of renal afferent arterioles

affiliation.orgName: Medical Faculty Mannheim, Research Division Cardiovascular Physiology
Centre for Biomedicine and Medical Technology Mannheim

analytic.title: Myoglobin facilitates angiotensin II-induced constriction of renal afferent arterioles

biblStruct.note: Submitted 5 July 2016; accepted in final form 30 December 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Vasoconstriction plays an important role in the development of acute kidney injury in rhabdomyolysis.
We hypothesized that myoglobin enhances the angiotensin II (ANG II) response in afferent arterioles by increasing superoxide and reducing nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability.
Afferent arterioles of C57Bl6 mice were isolated perfused, and vasoreactivity was analyzed using video microscopy.
NO bioavailability, superoxide concentration in the vessel wall, and changes in cytosolic calcium were measured using fluorescence techniques.
Myoglobin treatment (10 Ϫ5 M) did not change the basal arteriolar diameter during a 20-min period compared with control conditions.
N Gnitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME, 10 Ϫ4 M) and L-NAME ϩ myoglobin reduced diameters to 94.7 and 97.9% of the initial diameter, respectively.
Myoglobin or L-NAME enhanced the ANG II-induced constriction of arterioles compared with control (36.6 and 34.2%, respectively, vs. 65.9%).
Norepinephrine responses were not influenced by myoglobin.
Combined application of myoglobin and L-NAME further facilitated the ANG II response (7.0%).
Myoglobin or L-NAME decreased the NO-related fluorescence in arterioles similarly.
Myoglobin enhanced the superoxiderelated fluorescence, and tempol prevented this enhancement.
Tempol also partly prevented the myoglobin effect on the ANG II response.
Myoglobin increased the fura 2 fluorescence ratio (cytosolic calcium) during ANG II application (10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M).
The results suggest that the enhanced afferent arteriolar reactivity to ANG II is mainly due to a myoglobin-induced increase in superoxide and associated reduction in the NO bioavailability.
Signaling pathways for the augmented ANG II response include enhanced cytosolic calcium transients.
In conclusion, myoglobin may contribute to the afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction in this rhabdomyolysis model.

rhabdomyolysis; acute kidney injury; nitric oxide; calcium RHABDOMYOLYSIS-INDUCED acute kidney injury (AKI) is characterized by renal vasoconstriction (3), to which the activation of the renin-angiotensin system and the sympathetic nervous system may contribute (34).
The decreased renal blood flow is
also due to a reduced circulating blood volume by depletion of fluid in the damaged muscles (2), and to local mechanisms.
Myoglobin, which is released from the damaged muscles, may play a key role in this context.
Experiments in rats, where myoglobinuric AKI was induced by intramuscular injection of glycerol, suggested pre-and postglomerular vasoconstriction (32).
Furthermore, isolated perfused kidneys treated with myoglobin showed significant vasoconstriction and reduced glomerular filtration rate (12).
Myoglobin can be oxidized to metmyoglobin, which then redox cycles with ferrylmyoglobin and initiates lipid peroxidation (20,35).
Redox reactions of myoglobin are accompanied with the formation of superoxide radicals and other reactive oxygen species (29).
Increased lipid peroxidation is a feature of patients with rhabdomyolysis (13), and it results in the generation of vasoconstrictor F2-isoprostanes, which could subsequently decrease renal perfusion.
Vasodilatation of renal vessels is very likely affected in rhabdomyolysis as well.
Nitric oxide (NO), a main dilator component in the control of renal perfusion, interacts with activated ferrylmyoglobin species, thereby reducing metmyoglobin (7).
This observation may explain the beneficial effect of NO donors in experimental rhabdomyolysis (11,19).
NO treatment may also prevent renal vasoconstriction by balancing the NO reduction due to a scavenger effect of myoglobin.
Thus, the reduction of the NO bioavailability may be important for myoglobin-induced vasoconstriction.
So far, the direct effect of the myoglobin on afferent arterioles, which contribute significantly to the resistance of renal vasculature, remains to be unravelled.
In this context, the balance between angiotensin II (ANG II) and NO is of particular importance.
It has been shown in several studies that ANG II is an important vasoconstrictor in the renal vasculature.
Moreover, ANG II induces NO release and antagonizes its own vasoconstrictor effect (24,25).
This is also mentionable since NO has been identified as a major vasodilator in the kidney (21).
The activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system enhances the ANG II concentration in the kidney.
We hypothesize that myoglobin facilitates the vasoconstriction to ANG II in renal afferent arterioles, thus shifting the balance of vasoactive substances in favor of vasoconstrictors.
The generation of superoxide and the reduction of the NO bioavailability mediate this effect.
Animals.
Male C57BL6 mice (25-30 g), age between 3 and 6 mo, from Forschungseinrichtungen für Experimentelle Medizin, Charité-Universitaetsmedizin, Berlin, Germany, were fed dry rodent chow and tap water.
Handling of animals was performed in accordance with the regulations of the Office for Health and Social Matters of Berlin (Berlin, Germany).
Dissection and perfusion of isolated afferent arterioles.
Animals were anesthetized with isoflurane and killed by cervical dislocation.
Kidneys were removed and sliced along the corticomedullary axis.

Afferent arterioles attached to their glomeruli were manually dissected at 4°C with sharpened forceps and transferred to a thermoregulated chamber filled with bath solution (pH 7.4) on the stage of an inverted microscope, as described before (24).
Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) was used for dissection, as bath solution (0.1% albumin), and as perfusate for the arterioles (1% albumin).
Afferent arterioles were perfused by using concentric pipettes handmade from glass tubes (Vestavia Scientific, Vestavia Hills, AL) and assembled on an electronically controlled micromanipulator.
Two holding pipettes held the free end of an arteriole and of an attached glomerulus.
An inner pipette inside one of the holding pipettes was advanced in the lumen of the arteriole, thus providing flow to the arteriolar lumen.
Details of the procedure were described previously (24).
The pressure in the pressure head was 100 mmHg to mimic physiological flow conditions (flow of ~50 nl/min).
Perfusion of the arterioles was achieved within 120 min after the mice were euthanized in all experiments.
Vessels were warmed to 37°C.

The pressureinduced diameter of afferent arterioles and the response to high potassium chloride (KCl, 100 mM) applied for 10 s were used as criteria to identify vessels suitable for subsequent experiments.
The pressure in the pressure head was increased until vessels showed a clear lumen and wall.
Additional increase in the pressure up to 200 mmHg leads to a slight constriction or dilation of arterioles of ~15% compared with the initial situation.
Dilation of Ͼ15% led to an exclusion of arterioles from the experiment.
Furthermore, only arterioles showing an immediate and complete constriction in response to bath application of physiological salt solution containing 100 mM KCl were used for experiments.
Only one arteriole was used per animal.
Measurement of afferent arteriolar diameter.
The initial diameter was obtained in the beginning of the experiment.
The first part of these experiments consisted of a 20-min pretreatment period and time control, or control for resolvent.
Subsequently ANG II, at 10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M, or norepinephrine (NE), 10 Ϫ9 to 10 Ϫ5 M, was applied to the bath to obtain concentration-response curves.
Application time for each ANG II or NE concentration was 2 min.

The following separate protocols were performed: 1) control group: no pretreatment but time control, 2) application of myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M) to the perfusate during the whole experiments, 3) application of N G -nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME, 10 Ϫ4 M), a nonselective nitric oxide synthesis inhibitor, to the bath during the whole experiment, 4) application of myoglobin ϩ L-NAME to the lumen and bath, respectively, during the whole experiment, 5) application of SB-220025 (2 ϫ 10 Ϫ6 M), a specific inhibitor of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), to the bath during the whole experiments, 6) application of myoglobin ϩ SB-220025 to the lumen and bath during the whole experiment, 7) application of tempol (10 Ϫ4 M) during the whole experiment to the bath solution with and without myoglobin (lumen), and 8) application of L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M) and tempol (10 Ϫ4 M) during the whole experiment to the bath solution with and without myoglobin (bath and lumen).
The myoglobin concentration in the perfusion solution corresponds to that of patients with rhabdomyolysis (27).
Images of the perfused arterioles were continuously recorded using a digital videodisc recorder attached to the microscope's camera.
Digital pictures were serially acquired from the digital movie of each experiment and were used to measure arteriolar luminal diameter, as described previously (25).
The resolution of the measurement system was 12.53 pixels/m (see Fig. 1).
For each time or concentration of drug, five pictures were obtained within 5 s, and the average diameter was calculated.
In all series, the five pictures were taken during the last 15 s of each interval, i.e., in the 20-min pretreatment period every 5th min and in the concentration-response curve every 2nd min.
Data were used for statistical analysis of steady-state responses.
The data are presented as relative values (percentage of the initial diameter).
Quantification of NO in isolated afferent arterioles.

Perfused afferent arterioles were loaded with 4-amino-5 methylamino-2=,7=difluorofluorescein (DAF-FM) diacetate (2 ϫ 10 Ϫ5 M, dissolved in DMSO; final concentration of the solvent Ͻ0.5%) added to the bath solution for 40 -50 min at room temperature with a pressure of 30 mmHg in the pressure head.
DAF-FM diacetate is a highly sensitive photostable fluorescent probe for the detection of intracellular NO.
After loading, DAF-FM was washed out.
The pressure in the pressure head was set to 100 mmHg followed by an adaptation period of 10 min.
The perfusate was exchanged, and the experiment was performed for the following 20 min.

Three separate series were conducted as follows: 1) control group with vehicle solution for perfusion of the arteriole and bath, 2) a myoglobin group where myoglobin was applied in a concentration of 10 Ϫ5 M luminally, and 3) an L-NAME group.
Here, L-NAME was added to the bath solution 15 min before starting the 20-min recordings.
The aim was to test the effect of NO
synthesis inhibition on DAF-FM fluorescence.
The preparations were stimulated at 490 nm, and DAF-FM fluorescence images were acquired between 550 and 600 nm by using a customized set of filters (Chroma Technology, Bellows Falls, VT).
The DAF-FM fluorescence was recorded by using special software (VisiView; Visitron Systems, Munich, Germany).
The light intensity emitted by the arterioles was quantified by using the software Metamorph (Molecular Devices).
Acquisitions were made during a 20-min period.
The intensity values were averaged every minute.
Data are presented as relative changes (in relation to the initial value).
Quantification of reactive oxygen species in isolated afferent arterioles.

Perfused afferent arterioles were loaded with dihydroethidium (DHE, 2 ϫ 10 Ϫ5 M, dissolved in DMSO; final concentration of the solvent Ͻ0.5%) from the lumen and bath sides for 40 -50 min at room temperature.
The pressure in the pressure head was 30 mmHg.
After loading, DHE was washed out from the bath.
The pressure in the pressure head was set to 100 mmHg followed by an adaptation period of 10 min.
The perfusate was exchanged, and the experiment was performed for the next 5 min.

Three experimental protocols were conducted as follows: 1) a control group with vehicle solution in the perfusate and chamber, 2) a myoglobin group where myoglobin was applied from the luminal side in a concentration of 10 Ϫ5 M, and 3) a myoglobin ϩ tempol group.
Tempol (10 Ϫ4 M), a superoxide dismutase mimetic, was always present in the perfusate and bath solution during loading and recordings.

The preparations were stimulated at 380 and 490 nm, and fluorescence images were acquired between 400 and 450 nm (dihydroethidium) and 520 and 600 nm (oxyethidium), respectively, by using a customized set of filters.
The ratio of fluorescence intensity from oxyethidium and dihydroethidium was calculated and used as a measure for superoxide (10).
Changes of the DHE-to-fluorescence ratio were determined using special software (VisiView; Visitron Systems).
Acquisitions were made at 10-s intervals for 5 min.
The light intensity emitted by the arterioles was quantified by using the software Metamorph (Molecular Devices).
Quantification of the cytosolic calcium concentration in isolated afferent arterioles.

Perfused afferent arterioles were loaded with fura 2-acetoxymethyl ester (fura 2-AM, 10 Ϫ5 M, dissolved in DMSO, final concentration of the solvent Ͻ0.5%) added to the bath solution for 40 min at room temperature, with 30 mmHg pressure in the pressure head.
Fura 2-AM is a membrane-permeable fluorescent calcium indicator.
Once inside the cell, cellular esterases remove its acetoxymethyl groups to generate fura 2. During the loading time, one-half of the arterioles was treated with myoglobin for 20 min.
After wash out of fura 2-AM from the bath, pressure in the pressure head was set back to 100 mmHg.
ANG II, at 10 Ϫ11 to 10 Ϫ6 M, was applied to the bath solution with 2-min intervals for each concentration.

The preparations were stimulated at 340 and 380 nm and fura 2 fluorescence images were acquired from 470 to 550 nm by using a customized set of filters and special software (VisiView; Visitron Systems).
Acquisitions were made at 5-s intervals, and the last 20 s of each ANG II concentration were used.
The 340-to-380 nm ratio of the fura 2 fluorescence was calculated by using Metamorph software (Molecular Devices).
Because of the numerous uncertainties of the calibration of the fura 2 ratio in terms of absolute calcium concentrations, calibration was not attempted.
Instead, the 340/380 nm emission ratios were normalized to the response evoked by 10 Ϫ12 M ANG II to reduce vessel-tovessel variability.
Statistics.
All data are reported as means Ϯ SE; n is the number of animals.
Data were analyzed using an analysis of variance-like test for nonparametric statistics (4).
The program is available (the R-project, http://www.r-project.org).
This test is appropriate for the analysis of data with nonnormal distribution from experiments with a repeatedmeasurements design.

It provides information about the significance of differences between curves of repeated measurements (time or concentration dependent) and also the significance of time-or concentration-dependent changes for single curves.
P Ͻ 0.05 was used to reject the null hypothesis.
Reagents.

The following chemicals and drugs were used: albumin (ROTH, Karlsruhe, Germany), ANG II (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO), DAF-FM diacetate (Sigma-Aldrich), DMEM (GIBCO, Darmstadt, Germany), DMSO (AppliChem, Darmstadt, Germany), fura 2-AM (Invitrogen, Eugene, Oregon), isoflurane (Abbott, Baar, Switzerland), L-NAME (Sigma-Aldrich), tempol, NE, equine myoglobin (Sigma-Aldrich), and SB-220025 trihydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich).
ANG II, NE, L-NAME, and SB-220025 were dissolved in water and stored at Ϫ20°C.
Myoglobin was dissolved in water and stored at 4°C.
DAF-FM diacetate and fura 2-AM were dissolved in DMSO and stored at Ϫ20°C.

div.head: Myoglobin did not change basal afferent arteriolar diameter compared with control.

p.s: To study the effect of myoglobin on afferent arteriolar diameter, we treated the arterioles with myoglobin for 20 min in different experimental series.
As shown in Figs. 2, A and C, and 3, A and C, arteriolar diameters changed slightly in the presence of myoglobin.
The arteriolar diameter significantly increased from 9.9 Ϯ 0.7 to 10.4 Ϯ 0.6 m (105.2

Ϯ 2.2%, P Ͻ 0.01; Fig. 2, A and C) in the series F910 presented in Fig. 2, A and C. In the other series, diameter changes due to myoglobin were similarly small but did not reach significance (Fig. 3).
In both of the series, the myoglobin-treated vessels did not differ compared with the control vessels.
Also, the initial basal diameters of the control and myoglobin group did not differ in these experimental series (Figs.
2A and 3A).
Furthermore, vessels were treated with L-NAME to investigate the role of NO on afferent arteriolar diameter.
L-NAME significantly decreased arteriolar diameter to 94.7 Ϯ 2.7% (10.5 Ϯ 0.5 vs. 9.9 Ϯ 0.6 m, P Ͻ 0.001; Fig. 2, A and C).
The course of diameters was different compared with control and myoglobin treatment (P Ͻ 0.001 vs. control, P Ͻ 0.01 vs. myoglobin).

Treatment of arterioles with myoglobin and L-NAME together also decreased the diameter (to 97.9 Ϯ 1.7%, P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 2, A and C), and this was different compared with control (P Ͻ 0.01) but did not differ compared with L-NAME treatment.
Myoglobin enhanced the constriction to ANG II.
After 20 min pretreatment of the vessels with myoglobin, L-NAME, and myoglobin ϩ L-NAME, ANG II was added in increasing concentrations (10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M).
As shown in Fig. 2, ANG II in the absence of any agent constricted the vessels in a concentration-dependent manner.
Myoglobin significantly increased arteriolar responses to ANG II (P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 2, B and D).

L-NAME also augmented arteriolar responses to ANG II (P Ͻ 0.001), and this effect was in the combined presence of myoglobin ϩ L-NAME compared with myoglobin (P Ͻ 0.001; Fig. 2, B and D) and L-NAME (P Ͻ 0.05) alone.
Myoglobin did not modulate the response to NE.

After 20 min pretreatment of the vessels with myoglobin, NE was added to the bath solution in increasing concentrations (10 Ϫ9 to 10 Ϫ5 M). Figure 3 shows that myoglobin did not significantly influence arteriolar diameters during the 20-min period compared with the control group (Fig. 3, A and C).
Also, the concentration-response curve for NE in treated vessels was similar to that without myoglobin treatment (Fig. 3, B and D).
p38 MAPK did not mediate the myoglobin-evoked enhancement of ANG II-induced constriction.
ANG II-induced constriction of renal arterioles is related to p38 MAPK phosphorylation (18).
Thus, we tested the role of p38 MAPK in the myoglobin-evoked enhancement of ANG II-induced constriction using the p38 MAPK inhibitor SB-220025.
The inhibitor alone or in combination with myoglobin did not change the vascular diameter significantly compared with the control situation (Fig. 4, A and C).
ANG II in the presence of SB-220025 constricted the vessels in a concentration-dependent manner, which did not differ from the effect of ANG II alone (Fig. 4, B and D).
The response to ANG II was also significantly increased in the Myoglobin decreased the NO bioavailability in afferent arterioles.
To investigate whether myoglobin might influence NO bioavailability, we used the NO indicator DAF-FM.
Myoglobin significantly decreased DAF-FM fluorescence intensity compared with control (P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 5).
NO synthase blockade with L-NAME also decreased the DAF-FM fluorescence compared with controls (P Ͻ 0.001; Fig. 5).
Myoglobin increased superoxide generation in afferent arterioles.
Generation of reactive oxygen species plays an important role in the pathogenesis of AKI induced by myoglobin release.
To investigate whether myoglobin might enhance oxidative stress in the arterioles studied, we used DHE fluorescence.
Myoglobin significantly increased DHE fluorescence compared with control (P Ͻ 0.001; Fig. 6).
Tempol, a superoxide dismutase mimetic, blunted the myoglobin-induced increase of the DHE fluorescence (P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 6).
Tempol prevented partly the myoglobin effect on the ANG II response.
During the 20-min period, treatment with tempol (10 Ϫ4 M) increased the arteriolar diameter by ~18% (control 6%, P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 7, A and C).
However, tempol did not change the basal diameter in the presence of myoglobin significantly (Fig. 7, A and C).

Tempol prevented partly the myoglobin-induced strengthening of the ANG II response (P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 7, B and D) but did not exert influence on the ANG II response in the absence of myoglobin (Fig. 7D).
We further tested whether myoglobin affects the ANG II response by other mechanisms than increased superoxide and NO reduction.

During the 20-min period in resting vessels, combined treatment with L-NAME and tempol did not significantly influence the basal diameter in vessels with and without myoglobin treatment (Fig. 8, A and C).
The combination of myoglobin ϩ L-NAME ϩ tempol increased the ANG II response compared with the control situation (P Ͻ 0.01).

This effect was similar compared with that of the combined treatment of tempol ϩ L-NAME (Fig. 8, B and D), but it was less pronounced compared with the combination of myoglobin ϩ L-NAME (P Ͻ 0.05; Fig. 2).
Myoglobin enhanced the increase in the cytosolic calcium concentration in response to ANG II.
To study the role of cytosolic calcium for the increased ANG II response in the presence of myoglobin, we used fura 2 imaging (Fig. 9A).
Treatment with myoglobin for 20 min resulted in a stronger increase in the ANG II-induced change in cytosolic calcium (P Ͻ 0.01; Fig. 9B).
Myoglobin facilitated the ANG II-induced vasoconstriction in isolated perfused afferent arterioles of mice but did not influence the NE response.
Accordingly, ANG II-induced cytosolic calcium transients were increased by myoglobin application in afferent arterioles.
Myoglobin treatment increased superoxide and reduced NO bioavailability in the vessel wall.
These myoglobin effects may have particular importance for renal vasoconstriction in rhabdomyolysis-induced AKI.

The finding supports our hypothesis that increased superoxide and lack of NO due to myoglobin treatment are important components in the signaling responsible for the enhanced reactivity of arterioles to ANG II.
Manifold mechanisms pave the way of rhabdomyolysisinduced AKI.
In our in vitro setup, systemic influences can be excluded, and factors such as pH and oxygen pressure are controlled.
Under these conditions, the acute treatment with myoglobin from the luminal site of the vessel increased the ANG II-induced contraction of the afferent arteriole.
This may be due to the reduced NO bioavailability because ANG II via angiotensin type 1 receptor (AT 1 R) activates not only constrictor but also NO-mediated dilator pathways (24).
The finding that myoglobin does not increase the NE response supports this conclusion.

Interestingly, the luminal diameter slightly increased during the 20-min treatment period with myoglobin, similar to the control group, although the NO-related fluorescence of DAF-FM was reduced under the same conditions by 50%.

Such rather small effects of NO deficiency on the diameter of mouse afferent arterioles has been described in other studies before, suggesting that in the contractile state these vessels do not depend so much on NO in the absence of vasoconstrictors (25,26).
The present study underscores this observation.
However, the latter fails to clarify the diameter difference between the L-NAME-treated and myoglobintreated vessels, which are visible after 20 min treatment.
We cannot exclude the existence of dilating mechanisms acting during the myoglobin perfusion.
Notably, ANG II responses of afferent arterioles are more sensitive to NO deficiency (26).
Thus, L-NAME induced significantly stronger ANG II responses compared with myoglobin.
Furthermore, there was an additive effect of L-NAME and myoglobin on the ANG II response.
This additive effect suggests an additional mechanism, probably activated by superoxide, which strengthens the ANG II-induced reaction.
It also implies that NO deficiency may significantly worsen any myoglobin effect on the renal microvasculature.
The absolute basal diameters of the arterioles differed comparing the control, myoglobin, L-NAME, and myoglobin ϩ L-NAME group in the beginning of the experiment.

Also, after the 20-min period, i.e., before performing the ANG II concentration-response curve, the basal luminal diameter of the myoglobin ϩ L-NAME group was significantly greater compared with the other groups.
This is mainly due to two vessels of this group showing a diameter of ~15 m.
However, because body mass of mice was within the limits of 25-30 g and the age was below 6 mo, these vessels were not excluded from the study.
The relative changes in the diameter in response to ANG II were similar to the other experiments of the same group.
Therefore, we think that differences in the absolute diameters do not influence the result and conclusion of this study.

The mechanisms behind the reduction in the NO bioavailability in myoglobin-perfused arterioles are NO scavenging by myoglobin and a possible chemical interaction with myoglobin derivates such as metmyoglobin (7).
Our study shows an increased DHE fluorescence during myoglobin treatment that may mainly be due to the generation of superoxide, since tempol was able to prevent this effect.
Superoxide, which was increased in the wall of afferent arterioles during myoglobin perfusion, scavenges NO (1).
It is also well established that the superoxide anion attenuates soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulation by NO, and this may contribute to the reduced NO bioavailability in the present study (6,23).
Tempol dilated the vessels during resting conditions compared with the control, and it prevented partly the myoglobin-induced strengthening of the ANG II response.
This indicates a substantial role of superoxide in the myoglobin action on afferent arterioles.

The superoxide action includes NO scavenging; however, because treatment with myoglobin ϩ L-NAME induced stronger ANG II responses than the combined treatment of myoglobin, L-NAME, and tempol, additional ways of superoxide action can be assumed.
L-NAME and tempol together exerted a similar effect on the ANG II-induced constriction compared with myoglobin ϩ L-NAME ϩ tempol.
This observation suggests that the increased superoxide and reduced NO bioavailability are the main mechanisms of the myoglobin-induced increase in the ANG II response of afferent arterioles.
Notably, superoxide produced by NADPH oxidase 2 (NOX2) may be involved in the contractile response to ANG II in renal vessels (5).
ANG II activates NOX2 via AT 1 R in the vasculature, which in turn influences downstream signaling targets such as MAPK and RhoA/Rho kinase (22).
These groups of kinases are involved in the calcium-sensitizing pathways of smooth muscle contraction (30).
We tested the role of p38 MAPK, a prominent member of this group that is activated by several stressors (17).
It was shown previously that the adenosine-induced enhancement of ANG II responses in afferent arterioles involves an increased F914 phosphorylation of p38 MAPK (18).
Also, reactive oxygen species-mediated p38 MAPK phosphorylation has been shown to play a role in the development of vascular resistance in the apolipoprotein E-deficient mouse (28).

However, inhibition of the p38 MAPK by a specific blocker did not influence the effect of myoglobin in present study, suggesting no significant contribution of p38 MAPK in the myoglobin-enhanced ANG II response.
We used the p38 MAPK inhibitor SB-220025 because it is more specific than SB-203580 and does not inhibit adenosine transporters (14).
We cannot exclude that SB-220025 influences other kinases than p38 MAPK.

It also may influence signaling pathways via p38 MAPK, which are not primarily involved in the modulation of smooth muscle cell contraction but exert effects via modulation of inflammatory and other systems (16).
The fura 2 measurements indicate an increased response in the cytosolic calcium concentration to ANG II in myoglobinperfused arterioles.
Thus, the stronger ANG II response in the myoglobin-perfused arterioles is, at least partly, calcium mediated.
These fura 2 measurements agree with the finding of a reduced NO bioavailability in the arterioles.
The fluorescence studies in this study have limitations.
We could not distinguish between endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cells.
The fluorescence transients originate from both cell types.

ANG II acts not only via stimulation of AT 1 R and subsequent cytosolic calcium increase in vascular smooth muscle cells but may modulate the endothelial NO synthase activity via AT 1 R or AT 2 R, and cytosolic calcium concentration.
The volume part of endothelial cells is relatively small compared with vascular smooth muscle cells, which restricts their influence on the measured fluorescence.
One of the main mechanisms of NOinduced dilatation is decreasing the cytosolic calcium concentration via cGMP-and non-cGMP-dependent signaling pathways (9,15,31).
Thus, reduced NO bioavailability would go along with increased cytosolic calcium, as seen in the present study.
Also, ANG II and superoxide share pathways of contractile apparatus activation, which may influence cytosolic calcium concentrations (8).
It was shown that superoxide also increases the calcium entry through L-type channels activated by membrane depolarization in rat cortical afferent arterioles of rats (33).
This would fit our observation of increased cytosolic calcium, when vessels were treated with myoglobin.
In conclusion, myoglobin enhances the contraction of mouse isolated afferent arterioles to ANG II.
This goes along with increased superoxide concentration in the vessel wall and with reduced NO bioavailability.
The greater calcium transients to ANG II support the findings of increased reactivity of myoglobin-treated arterioles and reduced NO bioavailability.
The local effect of myoglobin on afferent arteriolar reactivity may contribute to the reduced renal perfusion in rhabdomyolysisinduced AKI.
Fig. 1.
Microphotography of an afferent arteriole showing the perfusion situation and the way of measuring luminal diameter.
A: untreated arteriole under basal conditions.
B: effect of ANG II application to the bath (end concentration 10 Ϫ8 M).
The site with the strongest reaction was taken for the determination of the ANG II effect on arteriolar diameter.
Fig. 2. Effect of myoglobin and N G -nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME) on afferent arteriolar diameter and on ANG II-induced constriction of afferent arterioles.

A and C: absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to perfusion with vehicle solution (control, n ϭ 16), myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 8), L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 9), or myoglobin ϩ L-NAME (n ϭ 7) during a 20-min treatment period (*P Ͻ 0.05).

B and D: absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to ANG II after pretreatment with vehicle solution (n ϭ 16), myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 8), L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 9), or myoglobin ϩ L-NAME (n ϭ 7, *significant group difference, all groups differ from one another).
Fig. 3. Effect of myoglobin on afferent arteriolar diameter and on norepinephrine (NE)-induced constriction of afferent arterioles.

A and C: absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to perfusion with vehicle solution (control, n ϭ 5) or myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 5) during a 20-min treatment period (no significant differences).
B and D: absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to NE after treatment with vehicle solution (n ϭ 5) or myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 5, no significant differences).
Fig. 4. Effect of the p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) inhibitor SB-22025 on diameter and ANG II-induced constriction of afferent arterioles.
Absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to perfusion with myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 8), SB-220025 (2 ϫ 10 Ϫ6 M, n ϭ 6), or myoglobin ϩ SB-220025 (n ϭ 8).
Data for myoglobin are the same as in Fig. 2. A and C: effect on arteriolar diameter during the 20-min treatment period.
B and D: effect on the vasoreactivity to ANG II (*significant group difference).
Fig. 5. Effect of myoglobin on NO bioavailability of afferent arterioles.

Relative changes in 4-amino-5 methylamino-2=,7=-difluorofluorescein (DAF-FM) fluorescence in afferent arterioles perfused with vehicle solution (control, n ϭ 6), myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 6), and L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 4) (*significant group difference).
Fig.6.
Effect of myoglobin on reactive oxygen species production of afferent arterioles.

Relative changes in dihydroethidium (DHE)-fluorescence ratio in afferent arterioles perfused with vehicle solution (control, n ϭ 6), myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 6), and myoglobin ϩ tempol (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 4) (*significant group difference).
Fig. 7. Effect of combined application of myoglobin and tempol on arteriolar diameter and ANG II responses.
A and C: absolute and relative changes in afferent arteriolar diameter in response to treatment with tempol (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 4) or myoglobin ϩ tempol (n ϭ 6).
B and D: effect of tempol (n ϭ 6) or myoglobin ϩ tempol (n ϭ 8) on vasoreactivity to ANG II.
Data for control and myoglobin are the same as in Fig. 2 (*significant group difference).
Fig. 8. Effect of combined treatment with myoglobin, L-NAME, and tempol on arteriolar diameter and ANG II responses.

A and C: absolute and relative changes of the basal afferent arteriolar diameter in response to treatment with L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M) ϩ tempol (10 Ϫ4 M, n ϭ 5) or myoglobin ϩ L-NAME ϩ tempol (n ϭ 7, no significant differences).
B and D: effect of L-NAME ϩ tempol (n ϭ 5) or myoglobin ϩ L-NAME ϩ tempol (n ϭ 7) on vasoreactivity to ANG II (no significant differences).
Fig. 9. Effect of myoglobin on the ANG II-induced change in cytosolic calcium of afferent arterioles.
A: change in the 340/380 ratio in response to cumulative doses of ANG II (10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M) in an untreated control arteriole (broken line) and in a myoglobin-treated arteriole (solid line).
A point of the x-scale corresponds to a 5-s measuring interval.
B: normalized 340/380 nm ratios in afferent arterioles perfused with vehicle solution (control, n ϭ 10) and myoglobin (10 Ϫ5 M, n ϭ 9) (*significant group difference).
